DOC.brief_summary: Nearly half of all patients with obstructive sleep apnea have insomnia symptoms, and in some, but not all cases, these insomnia symptoms are caused by the obstructive sleep apnea. The purpose of this study is to find out what type of insomnia symptoms are caused by obstructive sleep apnea and therefore most likely to respond to obstructive sleep apnea treatment with continuous positive airway pressure (also known as CPAP) and if additional treatment with cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia is beneficial.
DOC.criteria: 1. Sleep Apnea 2. Insomnia 3. Age >18 1. Sedative/psychoactive drug use recently 2. Other clinically significant sleep disorders 3. Previous treatment for OSA 4. Requires oxygen or bilevel PAP therapy 5. Clinically unstable medical condition 6. Recent shift work 7. Significant alcohol use 8. Other clinically significant causes of insomnia 9. Illicit drug use 10. Prescription stimulants 11. Safety restrictions 12. Unable to treat sleep apnea with positive airway pressure therapy 13. Communication barriers 14. Cognitive impairment
